children.value: The asynchronous, extensible, and magical .NET API wrapper library for Riot Games helps to make things totes' easier! ☆*:.｡.o(≧▽≦)o.｡.:*☆

Out-of-the-box naive caching, rate limiting, and retrying are available. Use the default
or include your own!

Make manual requests to the Riot API while taking full advantage of RiotBlossom's
features!
I just really wanted to use this emote...
RiotBlossom is an asynchronous, extensible, and magical Riot Games API wrapper library for C#. ☆*:.｡.o(≧▽≦)o.｡.:*☆

This library helps to make things totes' easier! Goodies include naive cache, rate limiter, and retry middleware plugins out of the box. Other services such as DataDragon and CommunityDragon are also supported! ＼(＾▽＾)／
This library is currently compatible with .NET 6 and higher.
API data comes as is from the source (Data transfer objects)
In-memory caching, spread rate limiting, and automatic retrying out of the box
Fluent client builder for advanced configuration
A highly configurable HTTP middleware system
Allows implementing your middleware (choosing a database to cache with)
Extensible subsystems (one for Riot API, one for the rest)
Reuseable data transfer objects, types, and exceptions
Tutorial: Get started with RiotBlossom using .NET Core CLI

This totes awesome tutorial will show you how to install RiotBlossom and make
a request to the Riot Games API using .NET Core CLI!
Open your preferred shell and enter the following command:

props.code: dotnet new console

children.value: This command will create source files within the current directory.

We will first need to install RiotBlossom from nuget.org, an online NuGet package
repository for .NET apps.

props.code: dotnet add package BlossomiShymae.RiotBlossom

children.value: With the package added, we can now fetch data from
to modify and save the code to something like this:

props.code: dotnet run

children.value: It should result in something similar to this:

props.code:
SummonerDto {
  "AccountId": "0WvZHECxpBFNlntYzcCNyDkGeaqA6vthcLsklngrPVYofWE",
  "ProfileIconId": 5367,
  "RevisionDate": 1675651090000,
  "Name": "uwuie time",
  "Id": "Ao5ffQ2dOV-99YKs_iB0g2EGzGD159jXIk2Z5MjvMafLwbQ",
  "Puuid": "Bd1zj7cFt3MlCZl2GI-5N94D2PHRsfpsjl-6ZM9LjXIm90Bz4JAdwR6Kw4fzbSPFfLoQI5p9hGIhfA",
  "SummonerLevel": 936
}

children.value:
Yay! You just learned how to get started with RiotBlossom in a .NET Core console
application!
Tutorial: Get started with RiotBlossom using ASP.NET Core and Visual Studio

This razor-sharp tutorial will show you how to install RiotBlossom and make a request
to the Riot Games API using ASP.NET Core and Visual Studio!
Create an ASP.NET Core Web API project
Visual Studio 2022 with ASP.NET and web development workloads
Create an ASP.NET Core Web API project
You will be given project templates to start from. Select the

The ASP.NET Core project template will be created with the necessary files needed
for a web application! :3
We will first need to add RiotBlossom to the project
on the right-hand side, right-click on the

With the package installed as a dependency, we should now be able to proceed with
configuring the services needed!
Modify and save the following code below to
// The default HSTS value is 30 days. You may want to change this for production scenarios, see https://aka.ms/aspnetcore-hsts.
The following line below is used to add a RiotBlossom instance of the type
since we need only one instance throughout the lifetime of our web application.

props.code: builder.services.AddSingleton<IRiotBlossomClient>(p => {});

children.value: What we are doing is registering an instance of
as a service for dependency injection. We can inject/pass this service through the constructor of anything hooked to
e.g. controllers, Razor pages, services, and more!

Notice that we have added an interface and class that we have not yet created,
particularly

props.code: builder.Services.AddSingleton<IConverter<string, Platform>, AcronymPlatformConverter>();

children.value: We will need a converter class for getting nicely formatted acronyms from platform identifiers used for League of Legends!
Go ahead and add the following to
That should be it with configuring services with dependency injection!

, modify and save the code
below:
button, the form will totes make a web request to

props.code: 'GET /summoner?summonerName=uwuie%20time&na1 HTTP/1.1'

children.value: , modify and save the code below:
Now we need to set up a Summoner page that receives our form
To set up a summoner page for receiving form data, we will need a new Razor page.
To create a new one, right-click on
Now modify and save the following code for

props.code:
@page @model my_riotblossom_app.Pages.SummonerModel @{ ViewData["Title"] = Model.ViewModel.Name; }
@Model.ViewModel.Level
@Model.ViewModel.Name
@Model.ViewModel.Platform

children.value: Whew. Now that we are able to fetch a summoner, let us run the app we made! <3
The following web page should be displayed:
Test the summoner search form by typing in
and pressing enter or clicking on search.
We should be able to get a minimal functioning summoner page!
This web application is far from perfect and can be improved! This for example:

props.code: /summoner?summonerName=uwuie%20time&na1

children.value: Could have used route parameters instead:

props.code: /summoner/na1/uwuie%20time

children.value: Yay! If you made it this far, thank you very much for completing this tutorial!

You just learned how to get started with RiotBlossom in an ASP.NET Core web
application!

links.text: Create an ASP.NET Core Web API project

children.value: Tutorial: Setting up application configuration in RiotBlossom

This coolsies tutorial will show you the basics of creating a client with RiotBlossom
using basic and advanced configurations!
For both minimal and advanced configurations, you can pass a
for the constructor/builder if you're only going to use
Do note that without a key, a
will be thrown when sending a request under the
Create a client using minimal configuration
To create a client with the least configuration possible:

It is a better practice to get our Riot API key from an environment variable instead of hard coding it as a string literal. The API key is a secret that can easily be leaked especially when using Git. :3

By default, RiotBlossom will create a client instance with spread rate limiting, in-memory
caching, and retrying enabled. An
will also be initialized internally for making web requests.
Create a client with advanced configuration

Creating a client with advanced configuration requires accessing the client builder
interface. This interface allows you to inject a

instance and configure
the middleware plugin systems directly! :3
The following code showcases an example of advanced configuration:

links.text: Create a client using minimal configuration
Create a client with advanced configuration

Let us try getting a summoner from the Riot API! Type and save the following

Tutorial: Making requests to DataDragon in RiotBlossom

DataDragon is Riot Games' static content delivery network that provides assets for
their game titles. In short, it provides images and information for stuffies like
League of Legends champions, runes, items, and more!
The code examples for this tutorial builds upon the tutorials overview!
DataDragon section of the following official documentation

DataDragon follows API versioning to ensure changes are made without disruption.
Versions usually follow the format of a League of Legends patch e.g.

. We
will be calling this a game version.
To fetch the list of game versions, type and save the following code below:

props.code: var versions = await client.DataDragon.ListVersionsAsync();

children.value:
The latest game version is the first on the list. Since this version is usually what
developers need, RiotBlossom offers a convenience method that allows you to do this:
// The above line is just a shorter way of doing this~
Now that we have our latest game version, we can now get champion information!
Gwen has the champion ID of
. Let us try to find out more about her:

props.code:
var champion = await client.DataDragon.GetChampionByIdAsync(version, 887);
Console.WriteLine(champion);

children.value: The following should be displayed within the console:

props.code:
Champion {
  "Id": "Gwen",
  "Key": "887",
  "Name": "Gwen",
  "Title": "The Hallowed Seamstress",
  "Image": {
    "Full": "Gwen.png",
    "Sprite": "champion1.png",       
    "Group": "champion",
    "X": 432,
    "Y": 0,
    "W": 48,
    "H": 48
  },
  ...
}

children.value:
It would be excellent to cache the champion hash map so that it is not requested
each time we need to get champion information:

props.code:
var championDictionary = await client.DataDragon.GetChampionDictionaryAsync(version);
var champion = championDictionary[887];

children.value: League of Legends runes are also called perks.
DataDragon offers perks under a perk styles tree e.g. "Domination", "Inspiration", "Sorcery".
, we know that the perk style ID is
The following should be shown within your console:

props.code:
PerkRune { "Id": 8214, "Key": "SummonAery", "Icon": "perk-images/Styles/Sorcery/SummonAery/SummonAery.png", "Name": "Summon Aery", "ShortDesc": "Your attacks and abilities send Aery to a target, damaging enemies or shielding allies.", "LongDesc": "Damaging enemy champions with basic attacks or abilities sends Aery to them, dealing 10 - 40 based on level (+0.1 AP) (+0.15 bonus AD).

Empower or protecting allies with abilities sends Aery to them, shielding them for 30 - 75 based on level (+0.22 AP) (+0.35 bonus AD).

Aery cannot be sent out again until she returns to you." }

children.value: "Your attacks and abilities send Aery to a target, damaging enemies or shielding allies."

"Damaging enemy champions with basic attacks or abilities sends Aery to them, dealing 10 - 40 based on level (+0.1 AP) (+0.15 bonus AD).

Empower or protecting allies with abilities sends Aery to them, shielding them for 30 - 75 based on level (+0.22 AP) (+0.35 bonus AD).

Aery cannot be sent out again until she returns to you."
It would be helpful if we can cache a single aggregate dictionary that contains all the perks:
League of Legends shop items are simply called items.
Moonstone Renewer has an item ID of
. Let us try to do the following:
The console should display the following infosies:
As always, caching is the totes better practice~*

props.code:
var itemDictionary = await client.DataDragon.GetItemDictionaryAsync(version);
var item = itemDictionary[6617];

children.value: You have just learned how to fetch game versions, champion meta info, perk meta info, and item meta info for DataDragon in RiotBlossom!
Tutorial: Making requests to CommunityDragon in RiotBlossom

CommunityDragon is an open-source organization that provides scraped data from
the League of Legends game client and the League Client Update (LCU). Developers
often prefer using CommunityDragon over DataDragon either due to the lack of
information provided or inaccuracies present in the game data for the latter.
The code examples for this tutorial builds upon the tutorials overview!

Champions in League of Legends have an identifier that is used for associating
information such as their name, statistics, lore, etc.
Taliyah has the champion ID of
. Let us try to find out more about her:

props.code:
var champion = await client.CommunityDragon.GetChampionByIdAsync(163);
Console.WriteLine(champion);

children.value: The following should be displayed within the console:

props.code:
Champion {
  "Id": 163,
  "Name": "Taliyah",
  "Alias": "Taliyah",
  "Title": "the Stoneweaver",
  "ShortBio": "Taliyah is a nomadic mage from Shurima, torn between teenage wonder and adult responsibility. She has crossed nearly all of Valoran on a journey to learn the true nature of her growing powers, though more recently she has returned to 
protect her tribe. Some have mistaken her compassion for weakness and paid the ultimate price—for beneath Taliyah's youthful demeanor is a will strong enough to move mountains, and a spirit fierce enough to make the earth itself tremble.",
  "TacticalInfo": {
    "Style": 10,
    "Difficulty": 2,
    "DamageType": "kMagic"
  },
  "PlaystyleInfo": {
    "Damage": 3,
    "Durability": 1,
    "CrowdControl": 2,
    "Mobility": 1,
    "Utility": 3
  },
  ...
}

children.value: "Taliyah is a nomadic mage from Shurima, torn between teenage wonder and adult responsibility. She has crossed nearly all of Valoran on a journey to learn the true nature of her growing powers, though more recently she has returned to

protect her tribe. Some have mistaken her compassion for weakness and paid the ultimate price—for beneath Taliyah's youthful demeanor is a will strong enough to move mountains, and a spirit fierce enough to make the earth itself tremble."

Unlike DataDragon, CommunityDragon does not provide a hash map for champion
information.
League of Legends runes are also called perks.
Summon Aery has a perk ID of
. Knowing that, we can do the following:

props.code:
var perk = await client.CommunityDragon.GetPerkRuneByIdAsync(8214);
Console.WriteLine(perk);

children.value: The following should be shown within your console:

props.code:
PerkRune { "Id": 8214, "Name": "Summon Aery", "MajorChangePatchVersion": "", "Tooltip": "Damaging enemy champions with basic attacks or abilities sends Aery to them, dealing @f5@ (+@f6@) (+@f7@).

Empower or protecting allies with abilities sends Aery to them, shielding them for @f8@ (+@f9@) (+@f10@).

Aery cannot be sent out again until she returns to you.


Aery has attacked enemies @f1@ times for a total of @f3@ damage.
Aery has helped allies @f2@ times, shielding a total of @f4@ damage.", "ShortDesc": "Your attacks and abilities send Aery to a target, damaging enemies or shielding allies.", "LongDesc": "Damaging enemy champions with basic attacks or abilities sends Aery to them, dealing 10 - 40 based on level (+0.1 AP) (+0.15 bonus AD).

Empower or protecting allies with abilities sends Aery to them, shielding them for 30 - 75 based on level (+0.22 AP) (+0.35 bonus AD).

Aery cannot be sent out again until she returns to you.", "RecommendationDescriptor": "Poke Damage", "IconPath": "/lol-game-data/assets/v1/perk-images/Styles/Sorcery/SummonAery/SummonAery.png", "EndOfGameStatDescs": [ "Damage Dealt: @eogvar1@", "Damage Shielded: @eogvar2@" ], "RecommendationDescriptorAttributes": {} }

children.value:
"Damaging enemy champions with basic attacks or abilities sends Aery to them, dealing @f5@ (+@f6@) (+@f7@).

Empower or protecting allies with abilities sends Aery to them, shielding them for @f8@ (+@f9@) (+@f10@).

Aery cannot be sent out again until she returns to you.


Aery has attacked enemies @f1@ times for a total of @f3@ damage.
Aery has helped allies @f2@ times, shielding a total of @f4@ damage."
"Your attacks and abilities send Aery to a target, damaging enemies or shielding allies."

Empower or protecting allies with abilities sends Aery to them, shielding them for 30 - 75 based on level (+0.22 AP) (+0.35 bonus AD).

Aery cannot be sent out again until she returns to you."

Caching the perks hash map would be totes amazing instead of having to request it
each time we need to get perk information:

props.code:
var perkDictionary = await client.CommunityDragon.GetPerkRuneDictionaryAsync();
var perk = perkDictionary[8214];

children.value: League of Legends shop items are simply called items.
Archangel's Staff has an item ID of
. Let us try do to the following:

props.code:
var item = await client.CommunityDragon.GetItemByIdAsync(3003);
Console.WriteLine(item);

children.value: The console should display the following infosies:

props.code:
Item { "Id": 3003, "Name": "Archangel's Staff", "Description": " 70 Ability Power
500 Mana
200 Health
10 Ability Haste

As always, caching is the totes better practice~*

props.code:
var itemDictionary = await client.CommunityDragon.GetItemDictionaryAsync();
var item = itemDictionary[3003];

children.value: You have just learned how to fetch champion meta info, perk meta info, and item meta info for CommunityDragon in RiotBlossom!
RiotBlossom serves three major API interfaces. Each of the major interfaces corresponds to an API supported by RiotBlossom:
This is how it corresponds to the codesies:

All API interfaces are meant for consumption, not for implementation.
This means that you will likely have breaking changes for the implemented interface for each version!
It is possible to make a low-level request via the

props.code: Task<T> GetAsync<T>(string route, string path)

children.value:
This will still take full advantage of the Riot middleware plugin system features (limiting, caching, and retrying if you have them set). Just provide a type for JSON deserialization!
( つ•̀ω•́)つ
// With great power comes great responsibility... OwO

The Riot Games minor interfaces correspond to endpoints provided by the Riot Games
API!
RiotBlossom uses pluggable middleware as part of the HTTP request-response cycle. Creating a middleware plugin requires implementing from any of the following interfaces:
As part of the HTTP request-response lifecycle:
Before the request is sent (request information goes through request middleware
On request (request function reference is passed to single retry middleware
After the response is received (response information goes through response middleware

.
A middleware stack is encapsulated to the APIs it is assigned to.
RiotBlossom client builder currently does the following:
- the Riot middleware stack for Riot APIs
- the Data middleware stack for CommunityDragon and DataDragon APIs
Each request processed under the Riot
is asynchronously locked per routing value to maintain data synchronization.
Having separate middleware systems offers more user configuration and flexibility in doing thingies. As an example, Riot
Hopefully, the system design was straightforward to understand...
if I had lost you, I am very sorry...
, action to invoke for continuing to the next request middleware. Not invoking will end the request middleware chain.
, action to invoke for sending cached data
, action to invoke for continuing to the next response middleware. Not invoking will end the response middleware chain.
, function to invoke for receiving an HTTP response
More documentation can be found in the
More documentation can be found in the
More documentation can be found in the
RiotBlossom does have custom exceptions it uses, so keep these in mind when using the client! 💚
when used will also throw standard exceptions that it cannot handle:
When crawling a large number of matches, it can happen on occasion to get a

match. RiotBlossom checks this
for you upon fetching a match or match timeline.
For more information, please see Riot Developer Relations
When all retries are used for a

When attempting to make a call to the Riot APIs without having a Riot API key set. This is designed so the CommunityDragon or
DataDragon APIs can be used without requiring an API key.
response was received in the HTTP request-response cycle for
When a rate limit was reached for

is true. Not to be confused with
the above exception where an actual HTTP
RiotBlossom uses types to represent named values used for the Riot Games API.
Represents the possible challenge levels for
Represents League ranked queue types for
Represents the available regional routing values used for Legends of Runeterra.
Represents Teamfight Tactics ranked queue types for
Represents the available platform routing values used for the Riot API (League of Legends).
Refer to Developer docs to better understand how routing values work.
Represents the available regional routing values used for the Riot API (League of Legends).
Refer to Developer docs to better understand how routing values work.
A structure of string constants is used for
Represents the available regional routing values used for VALORANT.
Public utilities are also offered for use in RiotBlossom!
Mappers and converters are included to get the raw or converted values of the aforementioned types in the previous section.
These are used internally for projecting values when making requests to the Riot APIs.
enum to a string representation used for the Riot API.

props.code:
// => "I"
LeagueDivisionMapper.GetValue(LeagueDivision.I);

children.value: enum to a string representation used for the Riot API.

props.code:
// => "RANKED_SOLO_5x5"
LeagueQueueMapper.GetValue(LeagueQueue.RankedSolo5x5);

children.value: enum to a string representation used for the Riot API.

props.code:
// => "IRON"
LeagueTierMapper.GetValue(LeagueTier.Iron);

children.value:
enum to a string representation used for the Riot API. Can also
be done the other way around!

props.code:
// => "sea"
LorRegionMapper.GetId(LorRegion.SouthEastAsia);

// => LorRegion.SouthEastAsia

children.value:
RiotBlossom uses simple objects with no behavior for JSON deserialization. These objects are strongly typed and are
close to 1-to-1 as possible for property names of the original data transfer objects received.
Data objects that have been commented as
do not have an official schema and are likely unstable between any versions. Use at your own risk. ⚠️
The complete directory of objects used can be found here under the
